s.text: Or so, at least, its recent (if short-lived) performance on the Internet suggests.

A few weeks ago, at a conference organized by Michael Mauboussin of Credit Suisse First Boston, Disney Imagineer Danny Hillis said that he thought Britannica's brand was so strong that once it got its act together, it would be a Web powerhouse.

A few weeks ago, at a conference organized by Michael Mauboussin of Credit Suisse First Boston, Disney Imagineer Danny Hillis said that he thought Britannica's brand was so strong that once it got its act together, it would be a Web powerhouse.

The company has actually been online since 1994, offering fee-based research, but the revamping marked Britannica's acknowledgement (one we Slate sters are very familiar with) that the Web and fees don't go together well, and its hope that its brand was powerful enough to make an advertising business work.
